title: Furniture shop owner jailed for 'insurance job' explosion which injured 81 people
text:

A furniture shop owner who deliberately caused an explosion that injured 81 people, has been jailed for 20 years.

The blast ripped through a street in the Wirral in March 2017 leaving 63 properties destroyed or damaged.

Pascal Blasio sparked the blast when he was a week or two away from insolvency, before filing an insurance claim for more than £50,000.

He was also sentenced to eight years for the fraud, to run concurrently,

The 57-year-old, who now lives in Kent, was found guilty of causing an explosion likely to endanger life and fraud in relation to the insurance claim, following an almost three-week long trial at Liverpool Crown Court.

The explosion rocked the community - leaving 142 people mentally and physically scarred.

(Image: Liverpool Echo)

(Image: Liverpool Echo)

Victims' injuries included multiple cuts from glass and debris, lacerations, burns and fractures while some people were left unconscious by the blast.

The most seriously injured was a 21-year-old man called Lewis Jones, who was sat outside the furniture shop in a bus stop and suffered devastating injuries to his lungs and kidney.

Investigators said it was a miracle nobody was killed while members of the emergency services said they had never experienced anything like it before.

Prosecutors branded the incident "apocalyptic."

In the lead-up to the blast, Blasio deliberately removed a blanking cap at the end of the gas pipe, using a tool, and also turned the emergency control valve turned allowing gas to flow towards the end of the pipe.

(Image: Julian Hamilton/Daily Mirror)

(Image: Liverpool Echo)

Afterwards, he submitted a fraudulent claim to NFU Mutual in relation to furniture that was allegedly lost or destroyed in the explosion.

Before Blasio's trial, Contract Natural Gas pleaded guilty to an offence under the Health and Safety at Work Act 1974 by failing to ensure that gas supply pipes were disconnected.

The company was fined £320,000 and ordered to pay £50,000 towards the prosecution costs.

Sentencing, Judge Thomas Teague said: "I have no doubt that you intended to cause an explosion large enough to demolish the building for it was crucial to your purpose that the entire contents of the building were destroyed...in any case partial destruction would expose the fact that you had emptied your showroom of most of the stock for which loss you intended to claim for," the Liverpool Echo reports.

“Your scheme could not succeed without completely demolishing this building and the adjoining dance school.

“It did not matter to you that the proprietors of the dance school...should lose their life’s work...it did not matter to you that the owners of the Chinese restaurant opposite would lose not only their homes but their livelihoods too.”

He added: “Prosecution counsel has said that it is a miracle that nobody was killed, I find it impossible to disagree with that assessment."

“During the trial with the dishonest help of your wife and son you had the selfishness to present yourself as a victim”

Judge Teague says there is an “obvious financial motive” for his actions and says a psychiatric report is completely unnecessary.

He added that the victim's statements in court were “deeply moving”.
description: Store owner Pascal Blasio deliberately sparked the explosion in the Wirral in March 2017
